Character cast is large, but for once almost everyone gets a decent slice of the story instead of being reduced to comedic window dressing the whole time.

These folks really cared about what they were making and it shows. The writing is excellent, the voicework is top notch, the music is catchy, background and character art and UI design are all well done, and really the whole experience is a cut above most of this game's contemporaries.

Kindred Spirits has quickly become my favorite yuri visual novel game, and is really a contender for the most well put together visual novel that I have ever played to be honest. It's right up there with the best of them.

I think the most important thing that this game does "right" that so many others fail to understand the importance of is (SPOILER:)  [spoiler]everyone gets a happy ending. This is so important and so needed because, while more and more VNs these days feature same sex romantic couples, which is fantastic to see, it's still very uncommon for a game to have some/all lesbian content and have it all end up with happy endings. So commonly do you see ones with really messed up scenes or just depressing results to their romances and it makes it hard to even enjoy playing games like that. Not so with Kindred Spirits, and that's so very important. We need more games like this one that leave you feeling good. We need more movies and TV shows with happy endings for same sex couples too for that matter[/spoiler].

There was one part in the game that actually did bother me personally. It was maybe 6 or 8 hours in to the game so not very far, and the way that the events played out seemed to run contrary to the tone and precedent of the game up until that point. Words were said by one of the characters to another that I felt were not healthy or "okay" at all, and actually rather cruel. Specifically I am speaking of (SPOILER:) [spoiler]the start of Kiri and Tsukuyo-sensei's relationship when Kiri confesses and Tsukuyo-sensei dismissed Kiri's feelings, telling her they were just a "misunderstanding" and a phase that younger girls often go through[/spoiler]. Thankfully though, as the game progressed, this issue that I had with it was actually addressed as part of the story, much to my pleasant surprise, and handled well enough overall that I felt okay about it after that turning point. I was impressed that the staff and writers went so far as to examine a scenario like that, and just knowing that they took that on only added to my respect for the game that Kindred Spirits became.

Another thing worth noting is that this game does feature some adult content scenes without even requiring a separate uncensor patch file to be downloaded. I think that's good progress on Valve's part for finally allowing this kind of content on Steam directly without having to have workarounds like we've seen up till now.

If you're concerned about the adult content, I was really surprised and pleased to see it was very tastefully handled and innocent. A lot of 18+ content games don't really know how to show loving relationships or innocence very well, and I believe it takes a skilled writer to be able to pull off tenderness in a lovemaking scene. Kindred Spirits succeeds wonderfully at this. If you were worried about the content being too graphic or vulgar, you've got nothing to fear here. The relationships take time to build before the intimacy happens, (SPOILER:) [spoiler]and the game's story takes place over the course of 8 months[/spoiler], so if you're going into this game expecting things to move quickly you'll be disappointed. I don't mean that in a bad way though. The character development and pacing is great, and by the time the scenes of intimacy come about, you really feel like you know the characters and the intricacies of their relationships well.

I know that no matter how good it is, Kindred Spirits on the Roof will be considered a "niche" title, because for some reason a lot of us humans are still not comfortable with the idea of women loving women even when represented as an artform, and on top of that, many people aren't even comfortable enough with their own bodies or sexuality to be okay with seeing sexual content in the games that they play.

If you ask me, it's unfortunate really that as a culture we're more okay with depictions of shocking violence, pain, and distress, than we are with sexuality and feeling good, but I digress. Chances are good most folks who fall into these categories aren't sitting here reading this review in the first place.

If you are the kind of person who is open minded enough to not let the fact that this game contains some scenes of an intimate and loving sexual nature between two women bother you, and you enjoy visual novel games, Kindred Spirits on the Roof is one VN you will really be able to appreciate, and its heartwarming story and characters will stay with you for a good while, and leave you feeling glad that you took the chance on it.

Full disclosure; I am a fan of anime and I am a guy. A guilty pleasure of mine is Nekopara and I have Steins Gate for the Vita. I am a fan of visual novels because I watch a lot of anime that derives from them and I enjoy video games with a healthy amount of good narrative or visual novel-esque mechanics.

I heard about this game because I saw an article online about it being an "uncensored" visual novel on Steam. So I looked up some promotional images for the game and liked the art style. I'm no expert on visual novels, but I've seen images from visual novels where the art isn't consistent. This game has a very consistent manga-like art style that looks good against the game's backgrounds as well.

I went into the game thinking this would be another guilty pleasure like Nekopara but found that I was actually enjoying it for multiple reasons without the need of "ecchi" distractions. Right from the beginning the game grabs me with its openning song. I'm a sucker for some anime songs and there are a few songs with vocals in this game that I really enjoy. The lyrics are nice too and the vocalized songs are sung by one of the character's voice actors, which I think is nice. It's all a bit romantic in a shoujo-esque way, though I guess the game is yuri.

A fault that I hear about in many visual novels, or anime inspired by visual novels, or just anime in general is that the protagonist is unrelateable because they're a blank slate for you to imagine yourself in their shoes, or that the protag is just a terrible one-dimensional character whose involvement in the story boils down to plot for "PLOT"; as in they have all sorts of plot armor, plot hole inducing nonsense to make them important, and for some reason everyone then likes them or rivals them for some reason or another, so they are justified in all the "ecchi" stuff they get coming their way. She has her own character which is developed and interesting and is part of a story within the game which is sort of seperate yet ties into her involvement with the other characters. What I mean by separate is that she isn't the focus of the game's ecchi story lines. Her own development stems more from her overcoming her own personal problems to become a stronger character that others rely on. Basically in a bad harem anime the protag gets unexplained plot power so that everyone is drawn to them. But in Yuna's case she isn't a harem protagonist, she's just trying to help other girls fall in love. This is difficult for Yuna because of her personal problems making her a bit of an introvert. But at her core she is a good person so she wants to help people when she knows she can. So she gets out of her comfort zone to help people. This makes her analyze herself and others and she comes to terms with why she was introverted in the first place so that she overcomes her problems. Basically she becomes a better character worthy of being relied on, capable of helping others, and therefore a justified protagonist.

So the focus of the plot is that Yuna helps girls who are lesbian find love. These girls have their own personalities told through their own narrative which explains how they feel about things, mainly their love interests. All the couples have their own quirks to them and whether or not you like the couples probably depends on the type of characters you like to see in a romance. People love shipping but tend to hate couples that don't meet their personal preferences. So obviously there were couples that I liked more than others for various reasons; some were cuter, some were more fun, some made more sense. But I liked the way the characters' narratives explained who they were and how they felt as characters. Regardless of what makes sense in the real world, I feel like all the couples are justified, more or less, by the characters' backstories, inner feelings, and interactions.

This review will be separated into three parts: TECHNICAL, WRITING, and OVERALL.

[h1]TECHNICAL[/h1]
On a surface level, this visual novel is surprisingly well-constructed. The artwork is crisp and well-drawn (artist is peg and you can find more of their work [url=https://www.pixiv.net/member_illust.php?id=5020]here![/url]), the score is pleasing to the ears and never feels worn out or tiring, and the sound direction is very solid. The dialogue text display is easy on the eyes by default (you can change the opacity of the dialogue text box). I would've chosen a slightly better font, but that's minor and entirely preferential. The voice actors chosen for this game (side note: not all the dialogue is voiced) are very skilled as is apparent by their work here. Not a single character felt like the VA behind them was mismatched, and a few of them absolutely shone out above the rest. The localization of the actual dialogue is also an extreme selling point. The folks at MangaGamer show genuine care for the product they are localizing for stateside release and it shows in the (verified!) high translation quality and stellar editing of the dialogue which helped give the visual novel life.

[h1]WRITING[/h1]
Once you get past the fact that the game revolves around a pair of lesbian ghosts, the visual novel is...surprisingly grounded in reality. The characters, for the most part, are realistic without being uninteresting (a few of the characters, specifically Koba Youka, I've grown to be very fond of and am astonished at how especially good their characterization was), and the interpersonal relationships are plausible without being lackluster. I haven't read the original Japanese text, so I can't verify if it was originally written as such or if it was the (high-grade) localization that makes it seem this way, but engaging with the dialogue in this visual novel was very rewarding throughout. This all being said, there was one relationship in particular that drew some mixed reception; the teacher-student relationship. In all honesty, it was somewhat awkward and felt a bit rushed, but it was nowhere close to a dealbreaker for me.

[h1]OVERALL[/h1]
I don't read many visual novels, but I do engage with plenty of yuri media. And Kindred Spirits on the Roof is one of the finest entries in both of those categories. Do I consider it worth the $34.99? Honestly, I don't know. It does seem to be a bit on the pricier side (especially since STEINS;GATE is the same price and that's longer and more comprehensive), so on the occasional chance that this visual novel goes on sale, please do get it. It's a truly fantastic work.

此外，《百合灵》的日历系统是一个亮点。游戏以每月为单位，玩家将先完成该月某几日女主角或百合灵为视角的剧情事件，再完成本月某几日出现的、与特定情侣相关并以情侣中其中一位为视角的剧情事件。日历界面同时也是存档点。这样的设计很利于玩家理清事件发生的先后顺序，且能很方便地回顾之前的某个剧情（不用去特意存档），十分爽快。日历系统也方便解锁完成一遍游戏后出现的附加剧情（与主线剧情中的选项相关）。

It is somewhat difficult to recommend Kindred Spirits on the Roof due to how niche it is. It has a number of love scenes with nudity, so that can be a reason for some people to avoid it. Then the quantity of such scenes is relatively low and they do not appear until several hours in, so it's not for people who just want porn either. Furthermore, the majority of the main cast are lesbians, so people who have a problem with homosexuality would have a problem with this title. There isn't much of an engaging central plot or gameplay elements, so it also is not for people who need such things to enjoy a visual novel.
All that said, Kindred Spirits on the Roof is an upbeat yuri romance visual novel with a character-driven story that is very highly recommended to everyone who is interested in such things.

What makes Kindred Spirits on the Roof feel so praiseworthy is the quality of its character writing. The main cast is relatively large and yet every character was relatable in some way and felt very believable. These characters have a good amount of depth and many undergo an appreciable amount of growth over the course of the story. The writing also does a fantastic job of conveying emotions. While not everyone will have the same experiences as those portrayed in this visual novel, the emotions that result from them are universal and this story presents them in a way that anyone can easily empathize with.

Unlike most other romance visual novels which feature one protagonist with multiple potential love interests and routes, Kindred Spirits on the Roof instead presents a single story with multiple couples. This allows the reader to view all the different sorts of relationships portrayed within the visual novel without having to read through it multiple times. At certain points in the story, the main storyline will stop and the reader will be presented with a few different scenes to select that focus on the various couples from the point of view of one of the characters involved. The main storyline will not resume until all scenes for each couple are viewed. There are dialogue choices to make, but the story is ultimately linear and the choices only impact the dialogue immediately following the decision while all choices must be viewed to unlock every extra scene after the main story is cleared.

As far as overall presentation, Kindred Spirits on the Roof has a respectable level of quality. Each character has a decent number of sprites and even multiple outfits. There are also over 50 event images and the art looks pretty good overall. The soundtrack consists of 11 background tracks, an opening, an ending, and one insert song as well as instrumental versions of the opening, ending, and insert song. The quantity is not particularly impressive, but there are enough tracks to convey all the emotions needed and they are put to good use. I personally enjoyed listening to each track. Translated lyrics for the songs that have them can be found in the music player accessed from the scene selection screen. In addition to the main story and couple scenes, there are over 70 extra scenes that become available after completion and provide even more content. My time on Steam is a bit off since I had a habit of leaving the program open so I could listen to the music as I took care of chores and such, but I feel confident in saying I spent over 40 hours with this title.

Kindred Spirits on the Roof is among my favorite visual novels and the best I have read on Steam. There are some aspects that would turn some people off from it, but for everyone else it is a title that I very highly recommend.

24801963.review:
When you see the thumbs down on this review, you'll probably be ready to either click "not helpful" or just scroll on past it. Fair enough!

Fact is, my feelings for this game are very, very mixed, but the reason I settled on giving it the negative rather than the positive were, believe it or not, mechanical reasons. And I don't mean the bug that forces you to quit the game every 10-20 minutes if you launch the game from Steam.

If the visual novel worked differently, I would probably recommend with much less hesitation, but because of how it works, not only am I instead giving it this negative review, but I may not even finish it (or at least not after a break) because I ended up just flat out getting fed up with it. 

If that sounds strange, as I'm sure it does, then read on. 

[b]The Basics[/b]

Truth be told, the writing in Kindred Spirits on the Roof isn't all that bad. The art, while not exactly incredible, is actually quite charming, and the characters are all look distinct from each other while still not having designs too outlandish or stereotypical. 

The story is about a girl who comes to find she can see two ghosts who have fallen in love and who want to help other girls find love at their school. The girl comes to assist their quest, and slowly but surely helps a handful of couples get together and stay together over the course of the story, eventually finding love herself along the way.

It's light hearted, and those without much experience with how these types of stories are written or how homosexuality is viewed in Japan might experience some culture shock when reading some of the dialogue, but the game is overall pleasant in tone and develops all of its characters fairly and in a decent enough manner. 

On the negative side, the soundtrack only seems to have a little over half a dozen or so songs (it feels like half that for the first few hours), and it reuses this same pair of peppy tracks in scenes where they really don't belong over and over again. The tracks that start to appear later in the game during more emotionally driven scenes are much more enjoyable and immersive, but that same pair of peppy songs always come in no matter what.

Looking at these things, the game probably doesn't sound too bad, right?

Well, if it was just this, I would be giving the thumbs up rather than thumbs down right here.

[b]How Kindred Spirits "Works" and Why It's A Problem[/b]

When you go into a visual novel, usually you expect to progress through the story from scene to scene, occasionally making choices along the way. If that sounds about right, as it so happens, there are actually exceptions to this that incorporate different types of gameplay or ways of moving from scenes: Kindred Spirits is in the latter category.

In Kindred Spirits, the player progresses by viewing scenes through a planner. First, they'll view scenes about the main story of the protagonist and two ghosts who want to help the students of the school they're haunting find love, and then progress in the main story is halted so that scenes from the perspective of the other characters can open up on your planner on the relevant days.

At first, this seems like a cool and novel system. You open up your planner, which serves as the game's menu, and not only look at any scene you've already seen, but progress through the story with a sense of time alongside you! As you start helping more and more couples, you'll have more and more scenes to go through between each portion of the main story, all taking place on different days, some taking place on the same days, which can really make your planner feel full and...

And that is where one of the big problems with this system starts.

I appreciate the system the game offers. The idea is interesting, and letting players see different perspectives this way could work, in theory.

But to me, it presented a big problem. As I see it, the problem could be taken in one of two ways: It makes problems for players who are either more interested in the main story and would like to keep following that, but it also makes it even worse for players don't care for whatever flavor of the day couple(s) the game insists you need to focus on before you can return to the protagonist. 

Because you [i]can't[/i] proceed with the main storyline or even with [i]other couples[/i] further down the road until you see the scenes the novel wants you to see in more or less the order it wants you to see them. In a normal visual novel, this sort of thing is usually handled in a few ways: multiple routes, unlockable [i]optional[/i] side scenes, or just being flat out kinetic.

By Kindred Spirits giving players the planner, it makes them feel like they have a level of control that the game doesn't actually give them. I would almost say the planner not only seems to only exist to give players the [i]illusion[/i] of having input in the story, but I might even go as far as to say that it takes control away. 

There were too many times where I found myself not enjoying the game because the game yanked me back into the planner and told me I needed to stop reading the story I might have been enjoying or invested in and go back and see what other characters were doing during this same period of time. The narrative had me jumping all over the game's different times, going back and forth from the end of the week to the start of it to earlier that month from various unrelated perspectives, and it created an experience that felt disjointed on more than one occasion. 

This could all have been avoided if there were an option to let me come back to these scenes at my leisure, or just not get to see them if I progressed past the points they were relevant. Presenting and writing them in a way where I didn't have to keep jumping back and forth to the planner would have worked out, but as it is, it feels like the author wasn't able to make scenes that flowed together as well, and so they needed to create a system that could circumvent them having to have every scene naturally move into the next. The fact that many scenes include recaps far more lengthy than necessary of what's going on in that character's life only adds to this issue. 

Putting the scenes into entirely separate routes would have even worked better. It might have meant players wouldn't get the whole story in one sitting, but you would get fuller, more fleshed out experiences as opposed to the slapdash back and forths you may not even want to read about that you have here.

Despite all of this, the fact is that [b]this isn't a problem if you can get invested in every scene of every couple[/b]. It isn't. But that also hinges on [i]also[/i] not wanting to see something that comes [i]after[/i] something that's included in "every scene of every couple." 

If that were the case with me, I would not be writing this in a negative light. Yet on more than one occasion, the game left the main story on a cliffhanger so that it could open up up to ten scenes for me to go through, some of which might be mundane, inconsequential, or ones that the main character was present for, meaning you don't actually get all that much from seeing the other side to begin with. It wastes your time doing that. 

You may finish a scene and be ready to go on to the next, then find rather than another scene of the main story, you have to play as the other girls for a while. And that may be it for you. There is no rhyme or reason to it - sometimes you get many scenes of the main story before the break to see the other girls, sometimes only a few. 

That may not be a problem for you, or it may be even worse for you than it was me, so with this in mind, here's my last thought on the matter:

[b]Take this with a grain of salt[/b].

Repeatedly getting yanked out of the main character's story for other ones without warning may have hurt this for me, but if it won't for you, consider this recommended.

To be honest, I expected only to come for the yuri and then, er, [i]come[/i] for the yuri, if you catch my drift. But despite my misgivings regarding potential fanservice and to-the-point meet-'n'-flick that all of the news sites seemed to expect of Steam's first uncensored game of "frank depictions of sex", this visual novel turned out to tackle issues related to struggling romance, including but not limited to struggling with sexuality, age gaps, and the idea of valuing other close relationships against romance, not to mention a social and fairly deep discussion on what it means to feel love. It is superbly well written and, at times, poignantly heartfelt; some of the dialogue comes off as awkward in a realistic way, in the scope of anime and manga, but it rarely ever feels cheesy. None of the referenced (meaning named and drawn) characters are cookie-cutter personalities; no obvious tsundere, dandere, yandere, whatever. Rather, they are all multifaceted, organic creations, and the underlying theme regarding the main character almost perfectly fits an Uncle Iroh quote: [spoiler]"Sometimes the best way to solve your own problems is to help someone else."[/spoiler] I surprised myself by becoming very emotionally involved with the characters and their stories, and ended up reading through this VN twice consecutively, and plan to listen to the drama CDs (by which I mean read the subtitles) when #4 is subbed and when they go on sale. Honestly, the explicit scenes are definitely not the end goal; they're nice to have and certainly demonstrate the different levels of experience, clumsiness, and passion between the different couples, but ultimately I found myself wanting to know more about the relationships themselves. There are uplifting and embarassing moments, heated and heartbreaking moments, funny and eye-rolling moments.

The technical side is also very charming and fitting with the theme of high school romance. Only the more important scenes are voiced, which is a feature I tend to like since it gives an enhanced sense of emotion and climax to certain story arcs. Each main story arc has a number of side story arcs focusing on the individual couples intersecting it. In this case, the planner approach is a stroke of genius. My one complaint on this end would probably be the difficulty in attaining the extra scenes, which are unlocked after completing the game and through selecting different choices throughout the game (the choices are very minor and only affect these extra scenes and some immediate dialogue; the story itself is linear). The music, though somewhat limited in choice and looped a little poorly, is tasteful for the different emotional stings throughout the game, from simple and melancholic to upbeat and driving. My two personal favorites are "Together", played during pivotal scenes in each relationship, with its melody seeming to display a collapse of willpower and the sort of heartthrob one gets from a perfect relationship, and "My Territory", which is a somewhat cheeky tune without any particularly distinct mood that plays a lot during important character-building scenes involving the main character at home.

In short, [i]Kindred Spirits on the Roof[/i] is a well-written game that deals with relationships, longing, and the sort of struggles that arise because of each character's unique dealings and personal hurdles. It's a little expensive at $35, but I believe it to be well worth the price.

My personal relationship ranking: [spoiler]Yuna x Hina > Sasa x Umi > Sachi x Megumi > Seina x Miki > Tsukuyo x Kiri > Youka x Aki > Matsuri x Miyu[/spoiler]. Although, I have to say, it's pretty hard choosing.

In my previous two playthroughs, I thought I played them all, but apparently that was not the case. The extra scenes add multiple layers of depth to every character, and they tie the entirety of the story back together in satisfying and emotional ways, sometimes heartwarming, and sometimes heartbreaking.

I've never written a review on here before, but for this VN, I simply have to. The shortest review I can possibly give would be one word: Masterpiece. I also feel that it would be irresponsible of me to give spoilers to the plot, as it is best experienced for yourself as you play through the game, so instead, I will try to take the middle road between brevity and gushing over this wonderfully touching story.

For starters, if you are looking at this game simply because it is a yuri visual novel and you're expecting to get some good wank material out of it, you may want to move along. They are not played up and fetishized, but are instead written in a sweet, pure way, genuinely fleshing out the feelings that the characters have for each other in a realistic way, as well as bringing up the worries of living in a traditional society that would see something wrong with them for feeling the way that they do.

In my opinion, the charm of this game lies in the attention to detail that went into fleshing out all its quirky characters. Some of them may fall into well-known cliches, but they do so in a manner that is endearing rather than grating, and thanks to the way their personalities interact with one another, all of them are deeper than just a collection of shallow categories.

Kindred Spirits is NOT a "porn game", and whilst this may come as a disappointment to some, I'd say it is actually one of its greatest strengths. "Fan"service such as pantyshots or ridiculously exaggerated breasts are thankfully absent here. Make no mistake: in spite of its spicy yuri scenes (tasteful nudity, in the words of the developer), this is ultimately a game about emotions, and you may find yourself laughing or crying with the characters as the story progresses. It took me a little bit to get used to the calendar you use to select and play/unlock the game's scenes, but I've quickly discovered its value in how it makes it easier to assume the role of different characters experiencing the same scene. + amazing artwork (including the chibis!)
+ (mostly) superb voice acting, in particular for some of the more emotional scenes
+ lots of content (extra scenes, song lyrics)
+ DEM FEELS (slice-of-life, slapstick, romantic comedy, drama)

For some context: I read a lot of visual novels, and I regret that. There's not really any other way to put it. I like the medium in theory, but the vast majority of what you can find is just bad. Pacing in particular is a problem, followed up by tendency to throw in reprehensible content.

Kindred Spirits is novel right off the bat because something actually happens in the first hour. While it's not immune to pacing problems, Kindred Spirits' plot moves along fairly regularly, aided by the device of the planner breaking the story into discrete chunks. Another thing that stops Kindred Spirits from feeling like it's stalling out is the fact that it follows a handful of couples, so someone's story is always advancing meaningfully whatever you're reading.

The couples are what is going to make it for you if you like the game. The characters are all unique and fairly well written, and the game for the most part does a really good job of differentiating the characters' internal monologues when there's a scene from their perspective. Yuna is an interesting character and one who I feel a lot of kinship with, but seeing the antics of the various couples as they fall in love and strive to start a relationship is bulk of the draw.

Well, I guess there's one other potential draw. The elephant in the room.

According to one of the translators, sexual scenes are only roughly 6% of the script. Having read all of it, I'm surprised it's even that high- and if sex scenes are 6% of the script, then things like "nngh" and "ahn" have to be at least 3%. I'm not a huge fan of sex scenes in these kind of games to begin with, but if you're going to have them Kindred Spirits' ones are fairly good. They do a decent job of making the people actually seem like teenagers who have no idea how to bone, and the CGs never get more explicit than a few anime tiddies. Unless you're incredibly morally offended by euphemistic reference to heavy petting you'll probably be fine- it's not like people are breaking out the dildos for a 50 page orgy.

One complaint you can level (aside from the pacing and editing, which, while WAY above VN standard, is still a little long sometimes)  is the "extra scenes". Once you finish the main story, you're only about half way done. Various scenes pop up all over the planner, and the main way they're unlocked is making choices in the main game. This is sort of a hassle, so I'd recommend just going back and choosing the other option every time you see a choice to get it out of the way early. The extra scenes are nice, but they're where the game threatens to outstay its welcome. Personally I was charmed enough to enjoy it right up until the final extra scene, but I suspect a lot of people will be done about halfway through the extras.

Also, the game makes you think it might have alternate routes, but that's a lie, choices only affect the extra scenes. Which is a shame, but there's nothing wrong with there being one story you want to tell.

In summary, Kindred Spirits is a cute little game that's a lot of fun. It lasted me about a month and I enjoyed my time with it.

Дисклеймер: некоторые части обзора оформились в хинты и переехали в комментарии; там же находятся ещё два дисклеймера.

Итак, зажигание – поехали. Пойдём от составляющих с наибольшим числом недостатков и с ускорением выйдем на орбиту, перейдя к тому, что [i]Kindred Spirits on the Roof[/i] удалось лучше всего.

[list]
[*] [b]Арт - 7/10[/b]
По сути, почти все баллы в этой категории достались за очаровательный чардиз. Лёгкий, воздушный, с тонкими линиями, приглушёнными цветами и пастельными тонами – полная противоположность уже изрядно надоевшей генеральной линии с выкрученной насыщенностью цветов и бликами на всех поверхностях. Обилие поз и их вариаций также добавляет и доставляет. А вот что не доставляет, так это недостаток числа фонов. Для ~25-часовой новеллы того, что есть, всё же маловато. И не забудем про славные 800x600, что было анахронизмом даже 4 года назад, когда VN вышла на родине. Хотя тут моё подозрение ложится вовсе не на сам арт, а на дремучий движок неясного происхождения.

[*] [b]Звук – 8/10[/b] 
И опять наблюдается недостаток, на этот раз числа тем. Да, для VN в ~25 часов этого мало: уже к середине прохождения саундтрек начинает приедаться, что малость грустновато, ибо к его качеству, к тому, как он усиливает настроение сцен, у меня нет ни малейших претензий. А, да, у новеллы малость странные представления о работе с BGM – вместо того, чтобы зациклить композицию, она зачем-то делает паузы. 
Но BGM на то и BGM, что основной тон сцен задают люди. Да, озвучены сцены только частично – около 1/5 от общей продолжительности. Но то, что за это время выдали сейю, перекрывает количество качеством. Все самые значимые, самые эмоциональные мгновения истории оживают именно стараниями актрис. И в первую очередь им удались не комедийные выходки, а интонации в повседневных эпизодах и драматические сцены, где речь героинь звучит расслабленно, естественно, вне шаблонов и типажей. 

[*] [b]История и повествование – 9/10[/b] 
Да, это kinetic novel, пусть и с разными POV, так что если вы не можете прожить без тысячи роутов, то стоит поразмыслить о Жизни, Вселенной и Всём Таком. Или опробовать демо. Кроме формата подачи, демо также прояснит ситуацию для тех, кто устал от сеттинга старшей школы в аниме и VN, либо вовсе к нему относится с подозрением. Но я советую дать [i]Kindred Spirits on the Roof[/i] шанс даже тем, кто, как и я, не любитель оного. Не побоюсь заявить, что написана новелла отлично, в чём заслуга как переводчиков, сумевших передать манеру речи каждой героини, так и сценаристов, грамотно балансирующих между юрийными тропами и реалистичными элементами, то «дискутируя» с этими тропами, то заигрывая и переворачивая их с ног на голову, то простукивая «четвёртую стену» шутками-минутками. Здесь соседствуют черты ромкома и slice of life (с очень большой долей будничности и быта даже по меркам этого жанра) с толикой мелодраматизма. Сама фабула не представляет собой чего-то эдакого, хитрых твистов почти не предусмотрено, а завязка кого-то вообще может отпугнуть. Но если вас зацепит демо, то, чем дальше, тем сильнее вас будет затягивать история жизни шестнадцати детально проработанных персонажей. И первым делом из всех на себя обращает внимание образцовая главная героиня. Она – голос разума в проекте двух немного мёртвых девушек, опора игрока, предвидящая случаи перехода в режим циничного критика, иной раз предугадывающая ваши реакции и комментарии. 
Если сравнивать, то [i]KSotR[/i] напоминает о такой живой классике своего жанра как Aoi Hana. Это не нечто вроде «Strawberry Panic!» с её восковым мирком в параллельном измерении, но и не ранние жанровые произведения с их театральным фатализмом. И, разумеется, эта VN на пару порядков умнее тех своих товарок, что плюют на эволюцию персонажей и окатывают потоком сахарного сиропа. В отличии от подобных пустых оболочек из целующихся школьниц, [i]Kindred Spirits on the Roof[/i], прежде всего, рассказ о преодолении трудностей на пути к счастью, о поиске и принятии себя – в том числе и своей сексуальности – который целиком держится на историях персонажей. Это искренняя и живая «история взросления» с кучей трогательных, смешных и душещипательных моментов, после которых даже через два десятка часов не хочется расставаться с полюбившимися персонажами и местами.
[/list]

[b]tl;dr - 8/10, а если забить на малозначимые недостатки и погрузиться в историю, то и того больше.[/b] Хина ставит "палец вверх", Ано просиживает ночами, Уми играет сама и заставляет подруг, Мегуми и Сачи...for scientific reasons, y'know.

It's almost bittersweet that I've reached the end of this so relatively quickly, though that has much more to do with spending the entire week dedicated to finishing through it.

A couple of things to note first off. I think the price-tag is still a bit steep, and I'd highly recommend watching this like a hawk for sales if you're truly interested in experiencing it. The demo will give you about the first 2 hours of story and introduce all of the characters. You can even carry over your save state from the demo since they're all held in simple files.

The other issue I've run into was performance. There's nothing about this VN that should cause stutters or lag, but I found consistently that I'd get about 20 minutes into a session and suddenly text speed would halve and the minimal on-screen movement of sprites would diminish even further than that. This problem might be localized, and it's ultimately a minor gripe, but I figured I'd give the heads up.

That said, I do highly recommend checking this out, especially if you're a fan of romance in any way. There's a lot to get into and there's a surprising amount to digest. The base game covers about 21 hours and the extra content delivers as many or more scenes in a smaller format for 5 hours.

Not a single moment is wasted driving the narrative. There are multiple points of comedy (Ano is an absolute trip), there are chances to cry, and there are points of pure catharsis. This novel is a bit unique in that sex drives the narrative, yet is never solely the focus. It would be unfair to say the erotic scenes don't serve their own purpose in character development, but they are simply moments where everything comes to a head.

I think the thing that impressed me the most in this is how organic the development of the main character is. I won't tell much, but it's very clear from the beginning that Yuna is not living entirely as herself. Her story perhaps more than any of the others is worth being read and appreciated.

Really, the thing that will make you enjoy this game is the sheer realism behind it in spite of its crazy, spirit-driven premise. A wide range of situations reach all of the characters, from the couple that have been in love for years but have had to hide it, to a new, entirely taboo affair between a teacher and student, to a 2 out of 3 couple that overthinks absolutely everything.

If it were any use, I'd write paragraphs on paragraphs about the merits of each individual character, and that's really where the biggest strength of Kindred Spirits on the Roof lies.

I don't think there ever has been or ever will be again this much adorable in one package.

Although the basic premise of the game revolves around sex, the story focuses on friendship and romance and overcoming life's challenges.  The actual sexual content is almost incidental, although I would still recommend for adults only.

While the game is expensive, it is also quite lengthy for a single route with bonus content, between 30 and 40 hours.  Normally I like to read for just a few hours at a time, to let a story marinate and let me immerse in its setting and characters and situations.  Although each scenario is relatively short, there's always something happening or something to look forward to or some reason to read just one more!  After the main route is completed the game opens up bonus scenarios equal to a small fandisk, which is good because no fandisks were made so this is all there is.  I wish there had been more of Hina's "wawawa" moments, but what there is is very good.

The music is suitably cute with a decent variety of tracks.  Early on they got repetitive, and the way they faded out then got loud again when they looped to the beginning was kinda distracting.  Days later though I will sometimes hear them sneak into my consciousness at relevant times.

The characters are central to the experience, and everything about them is spot-on: their basic design, art, poses, expressions, outfits, actions, and voices are all perfectly suited to them.  Sure some of them are a little stereotypical or tropic, but the story at least gives reasons for them to be the way they are.  The characters share moments that are cute, sweet, touching, and occasionally surprisingly hilarious, all while staying in character.  I couldn't help but cheer for all of them.

Two characters deserve special mention:  Hina is the most adorable ever, and Yuna's voice actress nailed it with a sweet-sounding voice I could listen to forever.

When it's all over, you're left with an ending theme by Rita that will keep me nostalgic for a long time to come.

Sachi-san, Megumi, Yuna, every day with you was so much fun.

I think Yurirei is smarter than both of those though.

To begin with, Yuna is neither ditzy nor particularly shy. Her mature, reliable personality is the freshest possible gasp of autumn air as a female protagonist. Her quiet confidence is intoxicating, her mannerisms are delightful, and I identify with the way she thinks immensely. She does have some of the cold and withdrawn characteristics that I see more often in male protagonists, such as the famous Tomoya Okazaki, but she is about twice as caring, 10 times smarter, and 100 times as responsible as that guy. Hina is also amazing, even more so as seen through Yuna's eyes. Her blunt cuteness is not some ____dere gimmick, but the main pillar of her personality, and she is, in many ways, just as responsible and intelligent as Yuna herself. 

In fact, in general, these writers seem to revel in introducing certain tropes, then annihilating them. In a low quality story, Aki would really just be an uptight prude that gets "broken in" by Youka. Then, their relationship would have no meaning beyond 'opposites attract.' Seina would just be a shy freshman. Tsukuyo would really be an incompetent teacher. Nena would just be a dumb girl that falls asleep all the time. In most stories of this type, I tend to think to myself, "How are these people so thick and clueless?" In Yurirei, I am just as likely to think, "Oh, I didn't realize she'd already thought about it that much." or "Whoa, that was quite perceptive."  

Ah, I fear I may have already spoiled too much. For maximum enjoyment, please go in blind now. 

*ahem*

The focus is on characterization, not panties; this is a story of romance, not sex: the uncertain confession, the embarassed atmosphere, the soft touch on the arm, tension, suspense, and ectasy. Their relationships develop in a way that feels natural, despite the manipulation by Yuna and our resident ghosts. Couples respect each others' boundaries, and they care deeply for each other. They plan their future together. They talk about how their parents or society might perceive them. Unnecessary fanservice is minimal, and even when kinky stuff finally starts happening, the art doesn't zoom in on their boobs, but does a great job of showing their expressions and body language; it is all rather sensual, and, imo, in very very good taste. 

Hence, in case you haven't figured it out yet, if you're buying this just to, uh, yuri your yuri, you're probably going to be extremely disappointed. 

However, if you're a true yuri lover like me (hehe), you will fall in love with this......as I have.

Let me start off by saying that I’m a gay girl and that I’ve been eyeing this game ever since it got released in Japan, which was back in 2012.

Was the wait worth it?

Hell yes.

As another reviewer has mentioned, this story does have a very porny premise.  Two ghosts rope MC into playing yuri cupid for various couples in the school so that the ghosts can spy on them and learn how to make love to each other, as girls—yes, this is morally questionable no matter how you word it—but despite this, the story is not centered around sex at all.  Really.  It took me around 12 hours to reach the first nsfw scene, and all the way up those 12 hours, the story focuses on developing relationships, emotional connections, friendship.  Rather than sex being the focal point of the game, it feels very much like a beautiful culmination to everything that couple has experienced together up to that point—from the confessions, to the trials and tribulations of trying get their love reciprocated, their sense of stability after ironing out misunderstandings.

Also, while the whole “b-but we’re both girls!” may seem excessive at some points, homosexuality in Japan is still very much condemned.  But that’s one of the most refreshing things about this game: not only does the story touch upon real issues like social stigma and family expectations, but it also doesn’t write off the girl/girl romances as just a phase, like so many other works in yuri genre do.  One couple in particular discusses and plans their future together in the face of a homophobic society, and that really resonated with me.

As someone who has also tried out the Sono Hanabira series, which oversexualizes girls (and even glosses over the fact that one of them is a huge age gap student/teacher lol), I am very happy that this game doesn’t treat homosexuality as a joke or something just to fetishize.  I really felt like the story was reaching out to girls in similar situations, living in fear of condemnation yet still brave enough to face their feelings and look forward to a brighter future.

Setting aside my accolades for the story, the voice acting, art, and music are also superb.  The nsfw scenes are very tasteful, and despite the fact that the OST is about 12/13 tracks, the songs are catchy enough that I never felt bothered by it.

Conclusion: if you love girls, love girls loving girls, love a good story, please get this game.  It’s $30, yes, but there’s around 30 hours of gameplay, so it’s well worth the money.  You won’t regret it.

So this was something I ended up playing on a whim. I saw this mentioned the week or so leading up to the game by a few people and I decided to give it a try since they had a demo avaliable. I'm extremely glad I did because this ended up being one of the best visual novels I've read, with wonderful characters and an emotinal plot. Though the game is rated 18+ and does contain sex scenes it's quite tame overall, and really doesn't even factor in until around halfway through the game. I was also surprised how the game tackles the subject of relationships, it doesn't pretend that they happen overnight or without some stumbling blocks. I mean the story is still pretty fluffly overall (it's about lesbian ghosts that wanna spread the lesbian around a school, c'mon) but I still think it took the romances realistically for the most part. Anyhow, let's break down what the pros, cons and nit-picks bout this game real quick.

Pros:
-A great main character, Yuna was delightful throughout. Almost all of the characters (barring one or two minor examples) are well written
-Emotionally engaging story, I'll admit I teared up quite a few times
-Satisfying ending
-Extra scenes that open up once you complete the main story
-OST is good, even if there are only about 12 tracks.
-Game takes relationships surprisingly seriously.

Cons:
-Some of the couples are just not as interesting as others, and the game makes you follow every side story
-Title is kinda weird. I read why it's that way but it's still weird.
-There ain't much porn if that's what you're here for.

Nit-Picks:
-I wish there had been just a bit more drama. I love the story but half the time the main character is just sitting around waiting for stuff to happen
-While the extra scenes after the main story were a nice touch, they were kind of pointless overall, to be blunt. While it did flesh out the relationships between some characters a bit more, they didn't do much for me. I'd have much preferred it if they'd given each of the couples a "one month later" epilogue or something
-Some of those songs in the OST, while good, might get annoying once they play for the 50th time
-I wish the game was longer. Though this should probably be a pro, I think this is one of the best compliments you can give a game. I wish there was a sequel, anime, something,
-By the way, if these ghosts wanted to see girls doing it, they DO have the internet. Feels like they could've solved this problem in 10 minutes. (I know not really, but still)

Overall the game was a delight to play, and I hope more similar games come soon. I don't usually replay visual novels, but I get the feeling I'm probably going to replay this one in the upcoming weeks. If I was giving this game a rating I'd say it's a 9/10
